She began climbing while helping in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, very flat country like Bangladesh most people have never seen a mountain. Her idea is working as fellow countrymen and women are watching with everyone else.

Most people think that poorer countries have big problems: having great poverty, have strong leaders, and with little hope for change. But this is not true at all. Really, a big change is happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have got more money and are not poor now. Also, less children die every year from illness, a lot more girls are in school, and millions of people have clean water to use.

To add some positive feedback, many managers use to say bad things nicely. However, when it happens often, workers can start to see good feedback as just hiding the bad, not important. Instead, good feedback should not simply be seen as something to make bad things easier, but should be used to help people improve.

I'm a member of the Group to Stop Dangerous Robots. Forget the movie image of a scary robot attacking people and think of what's happening right now: battle machines like drones, guns, and safety robots are already being used to kill with little help from people. The next step will be robots that pick who to hurt, doing what they are told. I think this would be very bad and unsafe for people. We need to be very careful about what we tell robots to do.

Generally, more people learn English than all other languages, and English is spoken in most countries. But Chinese has the most people who speak it from birth. There seems to be a small connection between how many people speak a language as their main language and how many people learn it, but there is a closer connection between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.

Your manager stops you and wants to talk about your work. You are worried all weekend about what thing you did wrong. On Monday morning, she starts by saying you did good work on the project, and you think this might be the usual 'feedback sandwich'. You know the 'feedback sandwich': say something good, then the true feedback, then something good again.

A fast, fun rock album, Born in the USA's words still have strong emotions. Behind the nice songs are talks about the bad side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the problems of hard-working normal people and the being sad and mad they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town remembering when they were young and felt very special, while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is spoiled when he loses his job. It's easy to think that the artist is thinking of real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become famous. The album will show you the special talent of Bruce Springsteen.

Lewis would like to see the number of safe areas in the sea move from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in a plan to fix the harm caused by people taking too many fish, making the water dirty, and leaving trash. On his trips, Lewis has seen this harm to nature near me. He's swum over coral losing color because the water is very warm, and seen places under the sea with no life and much plastic. Pugh thinks nature can heal if it has enough space, but time is almost up. If we don't start taking care of our seas, we may have a problem we can't fix.

Well-known writer Terrie Sharp is good at saying stories and has won a prize for stories twice. From a part of Glasgow with many problems, she learned to stay silent, stay out of trouble, and use a knife to open car doors. Luckily, she only used what she knows to write her books and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on TV shows and talking at meetings about stories in the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In the book, Steven Pinker looks at how people have gotten better and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the ideas of thinking and science are in danger. When people in media and leaders make people feel split, with no hope, and not trusting, then we are at risk of making problems we can't fix to important things like voting and helping everyone everywhere.

In older horror films, when main characters were in a very difficult situation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to keep it exciting? No phone signal! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you really need to call for help, you will not have any signal. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.

In the 1950s, Central American business banana growers were losing their best thing, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's next one – the Cavendish. With its easily moved, thick skin and sweet fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant was all over the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and seller in South America at the time, made many bananas in the most simple way possible: it made more parts from the parts of the plant instead of growing plants from seeds, and grew them in full fields.

Spider poison is found in most kinds of spiders and is for stopping or catching their food instead of attacking humans. Really, only 25 of the known spider kinds make poison which can really hurt humans, and although spider bites can hurt, they usually do not kill. Australia's known as dangerous Sydney funnel-web spider has not caused any deaths after medicine against poison was made in 1981. However, take care not to bother spiders like tarantulas. When they feel afraid, they protect themselves by throwing tiny itchy hairs. These itchy hairs then stay in the skin or eyes of someone bothering them.

This horror film idea was very popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most clever person ever. The last girl almost always wins in the end.

If we want to know how our how for difficult language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This is about more than just brain size; it is needed what other things our brains can do and when and why they changed that way. And for this there are very few clues; things left by our people from the past don't tell us what speech they were able to make. One thing we can see in the bones of early humans, however, is the change of the mouth, throat, and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had changed the how to make difficult noises. Before that, scientists who study how living things change can only guess whether or not early humans talked or shared information using more simple noises.

It is people, not the world, that tell us girls should like art and writing and leave maths and physics to the boys. Along with this is that there are few good examples of women young people see doing science jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, clever maker, or brave space worker as a man. Also, there is a wrong idea that scientists are into books, not good with people, or that their work is alone and away from others. These are wrong ideas shown on TV, but they may mean that girls do not feel like scientists, and see science as not a nice job. If girls saw more good examples of women in science it would give them more think they can and feel more part of those subjects.

The Scallion is printed weekly and given out for free in school buildings, with about 10,000 students who read it. It is made by only students. The check shows that the newspaper is liked a lot by university students and staff for fun, learning about culture, and learning to work. The cost of printing newspapers is big. Also, some students do not have an easy way to get the paper because the only way to get one is to actually go to university. Another problem is that many copies are trash on campus.

At Girox Foods, we are having workers leaving each year about 12 out of 100. But this might not seem high at first, the normal for companies like this is seven per cent. The main thing for this report is to know why workers' feeling here is not good and, from here, share ideas to make work nicer for workers and keep workers longer.

Much of what the speaker said seemed correct. I honestly believe it's a problem that the more connected we are, the more alone we feel. I don't think this is such a problem for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another situation. They're so busy talking that they never feel alone and might not learn how to be happy alone. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed instead of learning the art of face-to-face talking with the person in front of you.

Don't always use good comments with bad comments. When good and bad comments always come at the same time, the good things can become unimportant and not seen. Make sure there are times when good comments are given alone and try not to give helpful advice.

Your dreams might show you all kinds of thoughts about things that you didn't know you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean similar things in most people. But the key to knowing exactly what they mean to you is to link them to the things that happen and feelings in your daily life.

One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are about 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been left by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted very well to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs seem to know traffic lights.

Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with an unusual face on the street one day. Wonder has been a very popular book in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a way to start talking about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are very excited to see RJ Palacio's next book.

Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not common pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to tell people that rats aren't dirty and they make good pets if you look after them properly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how friendly and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

Cape Town can be a risky place for monkeys. Some have been hurt or killed in hits with cars and others have been hurt by power as they played with electric cables. Monkeys are a type of animal at risk, and to save them and stop fights between humans and monkeys, the city council has hired a team of Baboon Keepers. The keepers' job is to chase monkeys out of city places or catch them and let them go in places outside the city. This plan has done well, though it is hard to stop monkeys from coming back to the city when they find it as a place of easy food.

I work for a large technology company, but because their main office is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making small talk with colleagues. I work on different projects, and this freedom is important to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to plan a visit with the dentist. The disadvantage is that without clear office hours, I often work late into the evening, sometimes missing dinner to complete a job.

In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also a huge increase in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and made art to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more interested in making beautiful work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas, bringing color and beauty to grey, city walls.

Social media, magazines and shop windows overwhelm people daily with things to buy, and British shoppers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while big companies offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like items that can be thrown away – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

Sam watched the car kick up dust on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and swished their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter only visited when needed, which was okay with Sam. If he avoided his boss, he was able to keep his job. Mr. Carter wiped his sweaty neck. The sweat marks on his shirt came together. His skin was already turning red in the summer sun. Otherwise, he had the pale skin of a man who made money from others' work.

Many people living in Berlin, Germany said that shooting pigs was too cruel and there were fights between hunters and animal lovers. Because of complaints, the city council chose to act in a more quiet way against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it not allowed to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this plan works, though it may be a difficult job as warmer winters make more pigs than in the past.

An important idea for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of old Greek stories. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was about a brave person who defeats a monster. In this story, the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the people of Athens fight back. As a consequence, Minos the king of Crete forces the people of Athens to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the maze and eaten by a monster that lives there. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the monster and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a future Theseus.

By bringing people and animals together, zoos can show the public about saving animals and make people help animals and their living areas. Some zoos give a home for animals which have been treated badly in circuses, or pets which have been left behind. Zoos also do good studies into subjects like how animals act and how to help sick animals.

A different movement is starting against buying too much – the 'buy nothing' movement. The idea began in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a way of saying no to spending too much and using too much during the holiday weekend in November. On Buy Nothing Day people put together different kinds of protests and cut up their credit cards. All year long, Buy Nothing groups put together the swap and fix of things they have.

Is street painting art or damage? This depends on your opinion, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is seen as damage. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay money punishment. Many town leaders say they are unhappy about how much it costs to clean street painting off buildings, buses and trains.

What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing understanding of its value as an art form. There have been big shows of street art in galleries in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art show at a New York gallery in 2008. She supported street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely showing their ideas, not hurting anyone. They should be valued and praised'.

If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old, the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget most of our dreams, that's still some dreams we remember in a lifetime. It's easy to believe that, by coincidence, a dream is followed by a similar event in real life, especially if the dream is about something that happens often in daily life.

The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the end of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol has all the control over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they fought back against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into neighborhoods on the edge of the city to feed. They open trash cans and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be dangerous and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so clearly, many city residents don't welcome their being there.

Many bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often because of an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

George Lucas was one of the early film directors to build his story on the steps of a hero's adventure. Usually, the hero starts the story living a normal life, but they get a chance for an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is the invitation to adventure that starts the hero on his journey.

Another way to stop an asteroid going to hit Earth is to break it using a strong bomb. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was in the 1998 film Armageddon, but the NASA proposal called HAMMER is a real idea from NASA. The very heavy rockets would be fired at an asteroid coming with the hope of pushing it away. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to succeed, the rockets would carry strong bombs to break it instead.

As said by Campbell, the hero at first says no to the adventure, but a guide comes who helps them and they pick to start the journey and travel into the new place where the story takes place. The next part has tasks, fighting enemies, and meeting friends as the hero gets ready for their hardest test. For Luke, the guide is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the enemy base.

Rarely used items may seem useless to some, but could be a valuable thing to others. With the start of the internet, online communities have found a way to make money from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that help the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for sharing directly with others to take place. And this is called the sharing economy.

Around the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams show things hidden from our aware mind. Freud thought that if we know what dreams are saying, we can know our secret feelings and the problems they make. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a mix of random things in the brain while it sorts memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to understand these random pictures and feelings and turn them into some kind of story.

I'm a self-employed person and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many things that interrupt: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for different things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't good and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to use a desk in a shared office with five other self-employed people like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to concentrate better in an office.

Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized asteroids depends on getting the money to build a new telescope, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the team protecting the planet would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the dangerous asteroids.

The 'buy nothing' movement has now reached popular people online who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they suggest for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now ask their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months, they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes, or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up helpful things, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants, or buying gas for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is interested in other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim, and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to clear dreaming. Clear dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make choices to change what happens. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can lead the story of your dream like a movie creator. Then, instead of just understanding the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your hidden thoughts to tell you what's on your mind!

People might not see they are part of the problem with clothes that are thrown away because they give their no longer needed clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those no longer needed clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to use again; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge amounts are thrown away in the end, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent to other countries, making more money and nature problems.

Not happy with one great trip, some of today's people who love adventure go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most very special trip was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a big ice hole and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to keep going. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through very cold weather and strong storms.

Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. These days, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to get people who live there to think about the problem of homelessness.

In some areas, councils have tried to support artists not to paint graffiti without permission on walls by allowing them to work in special places. Taiwan is a place like this and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the local government has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to visit different places. Her work is found on pavements, in old factories and on old cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this shows how life changes with things ending and starting again.

In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a culture with a clear order where being in charge is valued and everyone has their correct place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a culture with less hierarchy where team members often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as helpers who help with new ideas and ask for suggestions.

When Gabriela saw the differences between her and her team, she decided to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Happy to give their ideas, Gabriela's team said that they were not used to being told what to do. They liked having more space for freedom to be creative. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she did not believe they could do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was upset when they tried to disagree with or change her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colorful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

People have been painting and writing on walls for a long time. Long ago, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Wall drawings have been found on buildings at old places in Greece, Italy, Syria, and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, people who study old things have found many cases of wall drawings written in Latin. These include messages about beliefs, government, love, and even some magic words!

Have you ever wanted to climb Mount Everest or walk to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's people who travel use new tools like GPS and special phones. Many people who travel are nature lovers who use their travels to tell people about different problems with nature, while others want to help people in need and collect money to help people.

The first is DART – a test to move an asteroid. Plans are planned to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, moving around its 800-metre main asteroid, and hopefully the hit from DART will knock it out of its orbit so telescopes on Earth can see it.

The heroine of the story, a sixteen-year-old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

Writing about your dreams will mean you start to think about more details of the dream, so consider the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the time of a week, you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start linking your dreams to the events and emotions in your daily life.

In the past, more bridges were made of wood and were much more likely to fire. This was especially true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch on fire and burn completely.

It is very difficult to know how street art will develop in the future, but certain trends are starting to be seen. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more attention or notice to street art as an accepted art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

Suzanne has always found news shows of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he was fighting in Vietnam. Her mother tried to keep her protected by not telling her what was going on in the war, but she still saw news shows about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very scary time for her.

In a survey done all over the world by a big company, more than 40,000 young people (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-young people answers were collected on the topics of work setting, how people talk and work, how people are paid, ways to grow in a job, having time for work and home, etc. In a different survey done all over the world by another big company, more than 10,000 young people joined a survey about their opinions of the problems and good things in the workplace.

Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a person who likes adventures. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. It’s surprising that Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to help people with difficulties to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips.

Online platforms are providing a chance for people to make some money. To give an example, busy parents didn’t use to have a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those barely used baby clothes that are too small for them now and the expensive baby strollers and baby equipment they have bought, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness, and exhaustion. They go through violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is filled with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast comes into view and everything changes. It would be sad to tell the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet time before her parents arrived home and the house got noisy in the evening with the sounds of talking, television or her dad listening to music he likes while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet animals.

In 2010, the space protection group at NASA had found and recorded 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth that are 1km across. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and are anything inside 50 million kilometers of Earth's path around. With a guessed 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a big threat to the planet.

Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is quite anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's a challenging experience. No one sits next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or whispering about him. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates are afraid they might catch something. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally a distressing event at a school camp changes things completely.

The two men looked towards the north side of the land. It went on for a long way. Even the fences were hard to see from where they stood. However troublesome a teenage boy might get, he couldn't run away. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, hitting the ground with its big feet. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a lot of trouble a good rider could have out here, far from other people. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty, have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in very cold weather and strong storms is still very risky, the top climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria became very interested in mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

After climbing Everest, Gerlinde wanted to climb all fourteen of the world's very high mountains. To make it harder, Gerlinde climbs without using air tanks. This is dangerous because there is not much air at the top, which can be bad for the brain and body. Gerlinde uses her popularity as a climber to help a group for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

If we look around us at the things we have bought at some point in our lives, we would see that not everything we own is useful: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked good even though we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves a new one, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the extra room in our house that turned into a storeroom.

Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or understanding. Even today, many people can remember when they dreamed about an event, place, or person and then, later, the dream happened in real life.

Some of the big and expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are key links that carry cars, trucks, and trains across rivers, mountains, or other roads. As a result, they are very important in building and are carefully checked, especially when they collapse.

After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

Dogs that live in groups have learned that humans usually give food to smaller, cuter dogs, so those dogs ask for food for everyone. Some dogs can even ride the city's metro to get from one part of their region to another! Experts do not know how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their very strong sense of smell and have learned to recognize smells of their preferred spots. Another possibility is that they recognize station names they hear from the loudspeaker. Anyway, metro passengers are now so used to seeing dogs on the trains that locals often do not notice them.

Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk along the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and reached the end of the river in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars, so Ed was always in danger. Luckily, he survived with only a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

In Britain, the typical person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more troubling developments for people and for nature. First, a lot of that spending habits is via credit cards. British people currently owe about £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's a significant portion of clothing expenses. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into waste disposal areas.

Ed's walk was impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the hardest areas. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, writing about his daily experiences. He used the interest from the news in his trip to talk about the harm of the rainforest and get money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

Businesses have seen the way to earn money from the sharing system and are trying to benefit from using those not fully used things. A business idea that many people like now sees companies giving a site that links customers with those who can provide a specific product or service. Companies like Airbnb help between for people to make money from their unused rooms and houses and let them out as money-making accommodation. Another example is Uber, which tells people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra money in their free time.

One of the most important jobs that zoos do is helping with plans to help animals with other countries, mostly for animals in danger. In the wild, some very rare animals have difficulty in finding mates and having babies, and they might also be in danger from hunters, losing their homes, and other animals. A good zoo will help these animals live and have babies in a safe place. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is a bigger risk of animals becoming too alike in their genes. Plans to help animals with other countries help keep them safe: zoo-bred animals can be set free in nature to change the genes.

Both of these kinds of accidents are not common, but boats and trains can make a bridge fall for different reasons. With trains, it's the speed of the hit that can make a bridge fall down. With boats, it's the big weight they have that can cause the bridge to fall, even if they are moving very slowly when it happens. The most effective way to stop bridges from falling is to plan for them. New tools that can detect weak parts, safer places to work, and better designs can all help to reduce these bad accidents.

At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he thinks about the hungry sharks in the water around him and realizes his only choice is to get back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat fight and eat each other, until only Pi and the tiger are left. Luckily for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is feeling sick from the sea and has no immediate interest in eating him.

When Pi is 16, new leaders are picked that his parents don't agree with. Worried about what will happen, Pi's parents choose to close the zoo and move to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family go by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a very bad storm and the ship sinks. Sadly, Pi's family and the ship's crew people all die in the water, but Pi ends up in a small boat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and a very big tiger.

The Hunger Games is a popular book for teenagers and young people by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was released in 2008, it has been translated into 26 languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

Maybe dreams are the outcome of our mind sorting the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with hidden meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like talks we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that manages language becomes less active while the part that manages feelings becomes more active.

Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family, and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – this means sharing personal feelings. Just one person for a deep talk is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is very important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

Person who likes the 'growth mindset' idea, Carol Dweck, spoke about how the brain can change and our chance to get better at skills that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to say good things about the final result and things you are good at naturally, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research says that by seeing how things are done – say good things about effort, test new ideas, and find answers to problems – we can help to learn new skills and keep getting better at talents.

The rover looks at the air around it sometimes, and in 2014 it found the air had another of the most basic natural substances and a key part of natural gas: methane. One of the things about methane is that it only lasts a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is adding more supply. According to NASA, Mars lets out a lot of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls during the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved the challenge and understood that their abilities could grow. She says they had a growth mindset and were focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and felt they had failed. They had a fixed mindset and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

Horror films love empty places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so silent, which can be very scary too. Of course, empty places are also helpful for movie directors in that it's more realistic that you will have no phone signal there either.

No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the dangerous person has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and usually damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always scary, even when there isn't anything down there.

Gary Collins, a policeman not working, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with finding out who people are. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and was able to find 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was very important in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, a computer program that recognizes faces was able to find just one person.

Personally, I think it's interesting to consider how we'll change faster by making our bodies better. Imagine adding a computer to our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our math skills, our perception, and memory, and this idea is only going to become more commonplace.

It was an interesting talk and the speaker really got it right with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also said something true about people wanting to be in more than one place at the same time. So they move between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.

As for news stories that make us think the world is a more violent place, there is some hope too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly living together more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has increased quickly in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the numbers are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of crime than war, the world murder rate went down a little, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has spent her time helping others and has seen many projects that help people in her homeland to teach and help women and girls, but they have nothing when these projects stop. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she put together her interest in climbing and people’s rights to try and change how people think about women in her country. She originally started climbing while working on help efforts in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign looks like it's working as people from her country are beginning to notice along with the rest of the world.

Most people think that poorer countries are in a very bad situation: having problems with very great poverty, ruled by unfair leaders, and with little hope for any important change. But, strangely, this is far from the truth. The truth is that a big change is happening. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Also, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school, and millions of people have access to clean water.

To try to give some good comments in what they say, many managers use negative feedback with two positive comments. However, when it becomes such a habit, workers can start to see good feedback as just to cover up the bad, making it less important. Instead, positive feedback should not just be thought of as something to make the bad parts less strong, but should be used to back up and help good work.

I'm a member of a team against bad robots. Forget the movie image of a scary robot crushing people and think of what's happening right now: army stuff like drones, areas with guns, and guard robots are already used to fight with little human control. The next step will be robots that work alone to fight, doing what they're told but choosing who to attack alone. It seems clear to me that this would be wrong and dangerous for people. We must be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

In general, more people are learning English than the other languages together, and English is spoken in the most countries. However, Chinese by far has the most people who speak it natively. There seems to be not much connection between how many people who speak it natively there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger connection between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk about your work in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you enter her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the necessary compliments that start off the normal feedback approach. You know how the feedback approach goes: say something nice, say what is important, say something nice again.

A quick, good rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics, however, are full of emotions. Behind the fun rock tunes that drive these great songs are stories of issues with the American dream. Many tracks deal with the difficulties of hard-working normal people and the sadness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is made worse when he loses his job. It's not hard to think that the artist is thinking about real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will make you certain of the great skill of the Boss.

Lewis would like to see the number of protected sea areas in the world increase from 3% to 10% in a way to fix the harm caused by human activity such as overfishing, making the water dirty, and littering. During his trips, Lewis has seen this harm to nature by himself. He's swum over coral reefs damaged by hotter water and saw empty areas under the water under the shallow water of the Red Sea, with no life and full of plastic. He thinks nature can get better if we let it, but time is short. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have a problem we can't fix on our hands.

Well-known writer Terrie Sharp can tell some good stories, having won a prize for crime stories twice. Born in an area with lots of crime in Glasgow, she learned to be quiet, stay out of trouble, and open car doors in a tricky way. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, talking on TV shows and at writing meetings in the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is improving an impossible goal? In a book by Steven Pinker, he looks at the basic thought of human improving and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the important ideas of reason and science are being attacked. When speakers and leaders try to make use of people's group thinking, giving up, and not trusting, then we are in danger of causing damage that can't be repaired to important ways like voting and working together between countries.

In older horror films, when the characters were in problems, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you really need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.

In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their best product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's new type – the Cavendish. With its easy to move, thick peel and sweet fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant was common on the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the big grower and seller in South America at the time, made many bananas in the easiest way possible: it copied the stems from the parts of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and grew them in fields close together.

Spider venom is found in most types and is used for making the animals they eat stop moving or killing them rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider types make venom which can really hurt humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are not often very bad. Australia's well-known Sydney funnel-web spider has not caused any deaths since medicine for spider bites was made in 1981. However, be careful not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel threatened, they keep themselves safe by throwing tiny bothersome hairs. These hairs then stick in the skin or eyes of the enemy.

This horror film familiar idea was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning, the girl is usually innocent, shy, and not very strong. By the end, she has become the strongest and best at solving problems in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.

If we want to know where our skill for difficult language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This is about more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they grew that way. And for this there are very few real hints; objects left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were able to make. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had grown the skill to create difficult sounds. Before that, scientists who study evolution can only guess whether or not early humans talked with more basic sounds.

It is people, not nature, that tell us girls should like arts, history, and languages and leave maths and physics to the boys. Also, there are not enough good female people children see doing science jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, very smart inventor, or brave astronaut as a man. Also, there is a wrong idea that scientists are unusual, have poor social skills, or that their work is alone and away from the rest of the world. These are false ideas shown by TV and movies, but they may mean that girls do not feel like they are with scientists, and see science as a not interesting job choice. If girls saw more good female people in science it would give them more believe in themselves and a better feel included in those subjects.

The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with an audience of about 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly appreciated by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural improvement, and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is large. Also, some students do not have an easy way to get the paper, since the only way to get a copy is to physically go to university. Another environmental problem is that a large number of copies become trash on campus.

At Girox Foods, we are having a yearly staff change of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first, the industry standard is seven per cent. The main goal of this report is to find out why employees stay interested within the firm and, from this, make suggestions to improve how employees feel at work and help employees stay.

So much of what the speaker said felt right. I honestly believe there is a risk that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are completely different. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and might not learn how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed instead of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.

Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback are always together, the positives can become not valued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given alone and try not to give helpful feedback.
